core_invention: A method for preparing an ionic conductive antifreeze supramolecular hydrogel.
mechanisms_principles: Based on four hydrogen bond supramolecular polymer with temperature-sensitive and pressure-sensitive properties, incorporating ionic liquid to provide conductivity and low freezing point.
formulations: PEG1000 (10g), chloroform (100mL), IPDI (4.5g), 2-aminobenzimidazole derivative (0.17g), PEG200 (1.8g), di-2-ethylhexanoic acid di-n-butyl tin catalyst (micro amount), ethyl acetate (for precipitation), ionic liquid salts: 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide, 1-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide, 1-octyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide, 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate.
manufacturing_methods: Step 1: Vacuum dry PEG1000 at 100°C for 1h, cool, stir in 100mL chloroform and heat to 60°C. Step 2: Dissolve 4.5g IPDI in 50mL chloroform, slowly add to mixture. Step 3: Add micro amount of di-2-ethylhexanoic acid di-n-butyl tin catalyst under argon at 60°C, stir for 2h. Step 4: Add 0.17g 2-aminobenzimidazole derivative and 1.8g PEG200, reflux for 2h. Step 5: Cool to room temperature, add ethyl acetate to precipitate white solid. Step 6: Wash with ethyl acetate, vacuum dry to obtain white semi-crystalline supramolecular polymer material.
equipment_used: Vacuum dryer, heating bath, stirrer, reflux apparatus, vacuum pump, filtration setup.
performance_data: Electrical resistance 80–150 kΩ at -20°C; swelling rates 300–700%; volume expansion 300–650%; suitable from room temperature to low temperature.
components_list: PEG1000, chloroform, IPDI, 2-aminobenzimidazole derivative, PEG200, di-2-ethylhexanoic acid di-n-butyl tin catalyst, ethyl acetate, ionic liquid salts.
concentration_ranges: PEG1000 10g, chloroform 100mL, IPDI 4.5g, 2-aminobenzimidazole derivative 0.17g, PEG200 1.8g, ionic liquid 0.5–1g per 10mL water.
functional_roles: PEG1000: polymer matrix; IPDI: crosslinker; di-2-ethylhexanoic acid di-n-butyl tin catalyst: catalyst; 2-aminobenzimidazole derivative: hydrogen bond donor; PEG200: plasticizer; ethyl acetate: precipitation solvent; ionic liquid: conductive filler.
process_parameters: Vacuum drying 100°C 1h, stirring 60°C 1h, reaction 60°C 2h, reflux 2h, cooling to room temperature.
application_instructions: Use as sensor or electrode in cold environments; can function as stress sensor or temperature sensor.
inventors: 张馨月, 马宁, 李博, 魏浩, 王国军, 欧阳肖, 张智嘉, 李瑞, 高闪, 王强
market_pain_points: Need for devices that operate effectively in extreme cold environments.

core_invention: An antifreeze composition comprising a freezing point depressant matrix of potassium acetate and monoethylene glycol, and a combination of branched organic acids (C5-C16) or their alkali/amino salts, and aliphatic mono/dibasic acids (C5-C12) or aromatic acids (C7-C18) or their substituted forms or salts.
mechanisms_principles: Improved thermal stability at low temperatures by preventing deposit formation, using branched acids as thermal stabilizers and aliphatic/dibasic or aromatic acids as additional stabilizers, while the matrix provides freezing point depression.
formulations: Composition comprises 50-99.8 wt% freezing point depressant matrix, 0.1-5 wt% branched organic acid (or its salt), and 0.1-5 wt% aliphatic mono acid (or its salt) or aromatic acid (or its salt). Optional additional components include corrosion inhibitors, antioxidants, anti-wear agents, detergents, and pH adjusters.
manufacturing_methods: Blend the corrosion inhibitor combination, optional additives, and monoethylene glycol depressant into the non-glycol based freezing point depressant matrix individually or in sub-combinations to formulate the antifreeze composition. Dilute the concentrate with water (10-90 vol% or 25-60 vol%) before use.
equipment_used: Glass vials for testing and climate chambers for maintaining specified temperatures.
performance_data: Less than 2% precipitate when chilled at 0°C for 24h; less than 1% precipitate when chilled at -15°C for 24h; less than 1 wt% precipitate when chilled at -25°C for 24h. Transparent after 24h at temperatures below 0°C, -5°C, -10°C, -20°C.
comparative_tests: Comparative examples 1-13 (43 wt% potassium formate, KOH pH 10.8-11.2), 14-35 (22 wt% potassium formate, 16 wt% potassium propionate, KOH pH 9.8-10.2), 36-38, 43-64, 39-42 (21 wt% potassium acetate, 28 wt% monoethylene glycol, KOH pH 8.8-9.2), 65-93 (22.8 wt% dipotassium adipinate, KOH pH 9.8-10.2).
failure_points: Scale formation from hard water, silicate deposition, precipitation of deposits, clogging of cooling system, reduced flow, increased engine temperatures, physical damage to seals and hoses.
alternative_embodiments: Various embodiments with different concentrations (e.g., 50-90 wt% matrix, 1-3 wt% branched acid, 1-3 wt% aliphatic mono acid), different acids selected, different water dilution ratios, different pH adjustment ranges (7-10, 8-9), optional additional corrosion inhibitors, antioxidants, anti-wear agents, detergents.
components_list: ['Potassium acetate', 'Monoethylene glycol', 'Branched organic acids (e.g., 2-ethylhexanoic acid, isononanoic acid, 3,5,5-trimethylhexanoic acid)', 'Aliphatic mono acids (octanoic, nonanoic, decanoic, undecanoic, dodecanoic, neodecanoic)', 'Aromatic acids (benzoic, etc.)', 'Corrosion inhibitors (borates, silicates, benzoates, nitrates, nitrites, molybdates, thiazoles)', 'Antioxidants', 'Anti-wear agents', 'Detergents', 'pH adjuster (NaOH)']
concentration_ranges: Matrix: 50-99.8 wt%; First component (branched acid): 0.1-10 wt%; Second component (aliphatic mono/dibasic/aromatic acid): 0.1-10 wt%; Optional corrosion inhibitors: 0.01-5 wt%; Antioxidants: 0.05-0.1 wt%; pH adjustment: KOH to achieve pH 7-10.
functional_roles: Matrix reduces freezing point; branched acid improves thermal stability; aliphatic/dibasic/aromatic acid further improves thermal stability; optional components provide corrosion inhibition, antioxidant, anti-wear, detergent, and pH adjustment.
process_parameters: Dilution with water 10-90 vol% or 25-60 vol%; KOH for pH 7-10; testing at 0°C, -15°C, -25°C for 24h.
application_instructions: Use as concentrate or dilute with water before use; maintain pH 7-10; store in appropriate containers.
property_tables: Table 1 codes for haziness, gel formation, flocculation, needles, precipitation with severity levels (Trace, Moderate, Severe).
inventors: Serge S. Lievenens, Jurgen P. Dekimpe
rd_direction: Development of antifreeze compositions with improved thermal stability at low temperatures and reduced deposit formation.
protected_claims: Claims 1-10 (English) and corresponding claims in German and French.
essential_claim_elements: Freezing point depressant matrix of potassium acetate and monoethylene glycol; combination of branched organic acids (C5-C16) or their salts; combination of aliphatic mono/dibasic acids (C5-C12) or aromatic acids (C7-C18) or their substituted forms or salts.

core_invention: Non‑freezing liquid containing a supercooling promoter composed of surfactants (non‑ionic, cationic, anionic).
mechanisms_principles: Inhibition of ice nucleus formation and promotion of supercooling at low concentrations of surfactants.
formulations: Non‑ionic surfactants, cationic surfactants, anionic surfactants.
performance_data: Supercooling activity measured as ΔT ranging from –10.1 °C to –5.5 °C depending on surfactant type and concentration.
comparative_tests: Comparison with AgI, NaCl, and other supercooling promoters showing higher ΔT for the surfactant‑based liquids.
components_list: Non‑ionic surfactants (e.g., Tween 80, polyoxyl ethers), cationic surfactants (e.g., hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide), anionic surfactants (e.g., sodium oleate).
functional_roles: Act as supercooling promoters that inhibit ice nucleation.
process_parameters: Concentration of surfactant, cooling rate (0.2 °C/min, 1.0 °C/min), temperature control.
application_instructions: Add surfactants to water at the specified concentrations to produce a non‑freezing liquid; can be used for biological material preservation, food storage, organ preservation, industrial cooling, etc.
inventors: 宇梶 慎子, 福士 幸治, 浦木 康光, 寺内 隆二, 高岡 尚生, 栃木 弘
market_pain_points: Need for low‑cost, easily obtainable supercooling agents that do not rely on expensive or temperature‑sensitive proteins.
target_markets: Biological material preservation, food preservation, organ transplantation, industrial cooling fluids, frost‑control applications, environmental ice‑crystal suppression.
protected_claims: Claims include a non‑freezing liquid containing surfactants and specific concentration ranges, as well as the inhibition of ice nucleation.
essential_claim_elements: Surfactants, supercooling promoter, non‑freezing liquid, concentration range.

core_invention: Coating composition comprising ionic liquid comprising a salt group and a first functional group, a film‑forming polymer comprising a second functional group, and a curing agent comprising a third functional group
mechanisms_principles: Anti‑icing by hydrogen bonding; film formation; curing via crosslinking
equipment_used: Fawcett air motor, DeVilbiss GTI spray gun, Gerson Elite paint strainer, Krüss Drop Shape Analyzer DSA100, Instron 5567, thermocouple, heating mantle, nitrogen inlet, condenser, stirrer
performance_data: Ice adhesion load reduced from ~1170 N (control) to ~907 N (5% ionic), contact angle increased from 84° to 92°, surface energy reduced from 43 mJ/m² to 37 mJ/m²
comparative_tests: Control vs 5% ionic liquid vs 10% ionic liquid coatings
components_list: ionic liquid, film‑forming polymer, curing agent, salt group, first functional group, second functional group, third functional group
functional_roles: ionic liquid provides anti‑icing properties; film‑forming polymer provides film formation; curing agent provides crosslinking
process_parameters: spray application, partial cure at ambient temperature (24‑40% RH) for 4 hours, optional baking at 140 °F (60 °C) for 1‑2 hours, dry film thickness 0.2 mils
application_instructions: spray coating onto substrate, allow to partially cure, then bake or cure at ambient
property_tables: Table 1B, Table 2A, Table 2B, Table 3B, Table 4A, Table 4B, Table 5A, Table 5B: contain contact angle, surface energy, ice adhesion load data
inventors: Steven E. Bowles, Hongying Zhou, Shanti Swarup, Bruce A. Connelly, Emily Chunderlik
protected_claims: Claim 1: A coating composition comprising an ionic liquid comprising a salt group and a first functional group, a film‑forming polymer comprising a second functional group, and a curing agent comprising a third functional group.

core_invention: Inflated regenerated cellulose fibers produced from ionic liquid/cellulose dope with effervescing agent
mechanisms_principles: Use of ionic liquid or quasi-ionic liquid to dissolve cellulose, incorporation of effervescing agent, activation to generate gas and create inflated structure
manufacturing_methods: Regenerating the cellulosic dope into a shaped article (fiber or film) by activation of effervescing agent in the dope
protected_claims: Method of making an inflated article of regenerated cellulose using a suitable ionic liquid or quasi-ionic liquid, incorporating an effervescing agent, activating it to generate gas, and regenerating into a shaped article with inflated structure

core_invention: Switchable solvent that reversibly converts between nonionic liquid and ionic liquid upon exposure to CO (or CS, COS).
mechanisms_principles: Reaction of amidine or guanidine with CO to form amidinium carbamate or bicarbonate salts, which can be reversed by removing CO.
performance_data: Conductivity increased from ~34 µS/cm to >200 µS/cm upon CO bubbling; viscosity increased; NMR chemical shifts observed for DBUHOCOR salts.
alternative_embodiments: Switchable solvents based on amidine or guanidine; using CO, CS, or COS as trigger; varying alcohol chain lengths; high pressure triggers.
components_list: Amidine or guanidine base (e.g., DBU), alcohol (e.g., 1-hexanol, 1-propanol), water, CO (or CS, COS).
functional_roles: Amidine/guanidine acts as base to form ionic species; alcohol/water acts as nucleophile; CO acts as trigger to switch.
application_instructions: Bubbling CO (or CS, COS) into the nonionic solvent to convert to ionic form; removal of CO reverses the conversion.
inventors: Philip G. Jessop, Charles A. Eckert, Charles L. Liotta, David J. Heldebrant.

core_invention: Stabilization and storage of therapeutic proteins using choline dihydrogen phosphate (CDHP) as a biocompatible ionic liquid
performance_data: Thermal transition midpoint temperature (Tm) of IL‑2 increased from 61.7 °C (30 mM NaHPO) to 74.2 °C (680 mM CDHP); enthalpy change of unfolding increased with CDHP concentration
components_list: CDHP, NaOAc, HEWL, IL‑2, trehalose, mannitol, glycerol, glucose, citrate, phosphate, bis(2,ethylhexyl)phosphate, bis(2,4,4‑trimethylpentyl)phosphinate, sodium chloride, choline chloride
concentration_ranges: 80% w/w CDHP, 0.1 M NaOAc, 30 mM CDHP, 40 mM CDHP, 20% w/w CDHP, 10 mg/ml HEWL, 1 mg/ml HEWL, 100 mg/ml HEWL
functional_roles: CDHP stabilizes proteins; NaOAc buffers pH; HEWL serves as model protein; IL‑2 is therapeutic protein
process_parameters: pH 6‑7.5; temperature 4‑40 °C; storage time up to 5 months; storage temperature room temperature
inventors: Gloria Elliott; Douglas MacFarlane; Chang B.S.; Hershenson S.; David M. Foureau; Iain McKillop
rd_direction: Development of a new formulation to enable sustained IL‑2 release in vivo
